newsitem.title: USA: McDonald's targets Burger King in new ad.
newsitem.headline: McDonald's targets Burger King in new ad.

text.p: McDonald's Corp is taking off the gloves and taking on its main competitor in a television advertising campaign to promote its french fries.

McDonald's launched a national television advertisement in late March targeting french fries made by competitor Burger King. The commercial shows a crew supposedly filming a bag of Burger King french fries while munching on McDonald's fries.
"We consider our fries to be the gold standard in the industry," McDonald's spokeswoman Anna Rozenich said. "No one can match them."

The french fry ad, created by advertising agency Leo Burnett Co in Chicago, is a departure for McDonald's. By its estimate, the fast-food company has not directly mentioned a competitor in its advertising for at least 10 years.

While McDonald's often promotes a particular product, its ads often have more of a "touchy, feely" quality to them, featuring happy families or its Ronald McDonald clown mascot, said Dennis Lombardi, director of restaurant consulting for Technomic Inc of Chicago.
"Burger King is the one, from a competitive perspective, that has had the biggest impact on McDonald's for two years," Dean Witter analyst David Adelman said.
By featuring its french fries, Adelman added, McDonald's is promoting a high-volume, high-margin product.
"For years and years and years, McDonald's fries had been one of its signature products," Lombardi said.

Advertising targeting a specific competitor, such as the french fry commercial, can be effective, as long as consumers do not consider them to be too mean-spirited, said Satya Menon, assistant professor of marketing at the University of Chicago.
"The information that they're getting out of the comparison is useful information," Menon said.

But the risk is that, while promoting its own brand, McDonald's is also putting its competitor in the consumer's mind, said John Lister, chief executive officer of Lister Butler Inc, a New York-based brand identity consultant.

"You cannot continue to run (this kind of) commercial. You are doing as much good for Burger King as you are for McDonald's," Lister said. "Why do you want to bring up the largest competitor's brand name?"
